segment.source: Enumerate and query files and folders
segment.target: Enumerate and query files and folders

segment.source: Access files and folders in either a folder, library, device, or network location.
segment.target: Access files and folders in either a folder, library, device, or network location.

segment.source: You can also query the files and folders in a location by constructing file and folder queries.
segment.target: You can also query the files and folders in a location by constructing file and folder queries.

segment.source: Enumerate and query files and folders
segment.target: Enumerate and query files and folders

segment.source: \[ Updated for UWP apps on Windows 10.
segment.target: \[ Updated for UWP apps on Windows 10.

segment.source: For Windows 8.x articles, see the archive \]
segment.target: For Windows 8.x articles, see the archive \]

segment.source: Access files and folders in either a folder, library, device, or network location.
segment.target: Access files and folders in either a folder, library, device, or network location.

segment.source: You can also query the files and folders in a location by constructing file and folder queries.
segment.target: You can also query the files and folders in a location by constructing file and folder queries.

segment.source: Note Also see the Folder enumeration sample.
segment.target: Note Also see the Folder enumeration sample.

segment.source: Prerequisites
segment.target: Prerequisites

segment.source: Understand async programming for Universal Windows Platform (UWP) apps
segment.target: Understand async programming for Universal Windows Platform (UWP) apps

segment.source: You can learn how to write asynchronous apps in C# or Visual Basic, see Call asynchronous APIs in C# or Visual Basic.
segment.target: You can learn how to write asynchronous apps in C# or Visual Basic, see Call asynchronous APIs in C# or Visual Basic.

segment.source: To learn how to write asynchronous apps in C++, see Asynchronous programming in C++.
segment.target: To learn how to write asynchronous apps in C++, see Asynchronous programming in C++.

segment.source: Access permissions to the location
segment.target: Access permissions to the location

segment.source: For example, the code in these examples require the picturesLibrary capability, but your location may require a different capability or no capability at all.
segment.target: For example, the code in these examples require the picturesLibrary capability, but your location may require a different capability or no capability at all.

segment.source: To learn more, see File access permissions.
segment.target: To learn more, see File access permissions.

segment.source: Enumerate files and folders in a location
segment.target: Enumerate files and folders in a location

segment.source: Note Remember to declare the picturesLibrary capability.
segment.target: Note Remember to declare the picturesLibrary capability.

segment.source: In this example we first use the StorageFolder.GetFilesAsync method to get all the files in the root folder of the PicturesLibrary (not in subfolders) and list the name of each file.
segment.target: In this example we first use the StorageFolder.GetFilesAsync method to get all the files in the root folder of the PicturesLibrary (not in subfolders) and list the name of each file.

segment.source: Next, we use the GetFoldersAsync method to get all the subfolders in the PicturesLibrary and list the name of each subfolder.
segment.target: Next, we use the GetFoldersAsync method to get all the subfolders in the PicturesLibrary and list the name of each subfolder.

segment.source: Note In C# or Visual Basic, remember to put the async keyword in the method declaration of any method in which you use the await operator.
segment.target: Note In C# or Visual Basic, remember to put the async keyword in the method declaration of any method in which you use the await operator.

segment.source: Alternatively, you can use the GetItemsAsync method to get all items (both files and subfolders) in a particular location.
segment.target: Alternatively, you can use the GetItemsAsync method to get all items (both files and subfolders) in a particular location.

segment.source: The following example uses the GetItemsAsync method to get all files and subfolders in the root folder of the PicturesLibrary (not in subfolders).
segment.target: The following example uses the GetItemsAsync method to get all files and subfolders in the root folder of the PicturesLibrary (not in subfolders).

segment.source: Then the example lists the name of each file and subfolder.
segment.target: Then the example lists the name of each file and subfolder.

segment.source: If the item is a subfolder, the example appends to the name.
segment.target: If the item is a subfolder, the example appends to the name.

segment.source: Query files in a location and enumerate matching files
segment.target: Query files in a location and enumerate matching files

segment.source: In this example we query for all the files in the PicturesLibrary grouped by the month, and this time the example recurses into subfolders.
segment.target: In this example we query for all the files in the PicturesLibrary grouped by the month, and this time the example recurses into subfolders.

segment.source: First, we call StorageFolder.CreateFolderQuery and pass the CommonFolderQuery.GroupByMonth value to the method.
segment.target: First, we call StorageFolder.CreateFolderQuery and pass the CommonFolderQuery.GroupByMonth value to the method.

segment.source: That gives us a StorageFolderQueryResult object.
segment.target: That gives us a StorageFolderQueryResult object.

segment.source: Next we call StorageFolderQueryResult.GetFoldersAsync which returns StorageFolder objects representing virtual folders.
segment.target: Next we call StorageFolderQueryResult.GetFoldersAsync which returns StorageFolder objects representing virtual folders.

segment.source: In this case we're grouping by month, so the virtual folders each represent a group of files with the same month.
segment.target: In this case we're grouping by month, so the virtual folders each represent a group of files with the same month.

segment.source: The output of the example looks similar to the following.
segment.target: The output of the example looks similar to the following.
